div1.p: These documents detail the entire military history of Reed. They also include announcements of Reed's death. The documents are dated November 1, 1902 through December 8, 1902. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Surgeon General's Office Record Card for Walter Reed, November 1, 1902
div1.p: K.

2d Indorsement.
Nov. 1, 1901.
Resp. ret. to the A.G. of the Army.

Maj. Walter Reed is a profes-
sor in the Army Med. School and
could not leave, at the time men-
tioned, to attend the health con-
vention in Michigan without seri-
ous interference with the course
of instruction prescribed. Twenty
young med. officers have been or-
dered to Washington to take this
course and Maj. Reed's presence
is absolutely necessary during
the entire month of Nov.

G.M.S., S.G.
FC

Military History of Major Wal-
ter Reed, Surg. U.S.A., so far as
shown by the records of the S.G.O.

Maj. Walter Reed, Surg. U.S.A. was
appointed Asst. Surgeon, U.S.A., June
26, 1875, accepted July 3, 1875, and
was on duty as follows:

En route and on duty at Willets
Point, N.Y., from July 23, 1875 to
April 14, 1876, during which time
was on leave of absence from Oct.
8, 1875 to Oct. 15, 1875, and from Feb.
26, 1876 to March 6, 1876;

Reported at New York City, N.Y.
general recruiting service to ac-
company troops to California April
15, 1876;

Under and awaiting orders at
Harrisonburg, Va., and en route to
Dept. of California with recruits
from New York City, N.Y., from April
15, 1876 to May 21, 1876;

En route to and on duty at Camp Low-
ell, Arizona, from Aug. 5, 1876 to Aug.
10, 1877, during which time was on
leave of absence from Oct. 10, 1876
to Dec. 7, 1876;

En route to and on duty at
Camp Apache, Arizona, from Aug. 10,
1877 to May 10, 1880, during which
time was on detached service at
Stensons Ranch, Arizona Territory
March 9 to 15, 1878 - on leave of ab-
sence from April 2, 1879 to May 14,
1879 - in the field from May 29,
1879 to June 3, 1879 - in the field
with scouting party from Dec. 17,
1879 to Dec. 23, 1879;

On leave of absence June 9,
1880 to Aug. 8, 1880.

Promoted Asst. Surg. with the
rank of Capt. June 26, 1880;

At Warrenton, Va., awaiting or-
ders Aug. 9, 1880 to Aug. 31, 1880;

Awaiting orders at Hdqrs. Dept.
of the East Sept. 19 to 23, 1880;

At Ft. McHenry, Md., on detached
duty with troops and awaiting or-
ders from Feby. 24, 1881 to May 2,
1881;

At Washington Barracks, D.C.,
from May 2, 1881 to Nov. 17, 1882,
during which time was en route to
and on duty with troops at York-
town, Va., from Oct. 1, 1881 to Nov.
12, 1881.

Examined for promotion at
New York City, N.Y., and found quali-
fied March 1882. En route to and
on duty with troops in summer Camp
at Gaithersburg, Md., from June 23,
1882 to Nov. 2, 1882;

At Ft. Omaha, Neb., from Jan. 2,
1883 to Oct. 4, 1883, during which
time was on leave of absence Sept.
30, 1883 to Oct. 3, 1883;

At Ft. Sidney, Neb., from Oct. 5,
1883 to Aug. 4, 1884;

At Ft. Robinson, Neb., from Aug.
8, 1884 to July 31, 1887, during which
time he was on leave of absence
from Dec. 3, 1885 to Jan. 26, 1886.
Sick at station March 6 to 18, 1886.

En route to Mt Vernon Barracks
Ala., for duty July 31, to Aug. 5, 1887
at Mt. Vernon Barracks, Ala., Aug. 5,
1887 to Oct. 6, 1890, during which
time was on leave of absence Feb.
12 to 16, 1889 - on detached duty
with Lt. Cunningham 19th Inf. to
Govt. Hospital for the Insane Dec.
31, 1889 to Jan. 5. 1890. On leave of
absence from Sept. 8, 1890 to Octo-
ber 6, 1890.

At Balto, Md., Attending Surg.
and Examiner of Recruits from Oct.
6, 1890 to Oct. 31, 1891, during which
time was en route to and on tem-
porary duty at Ft. Keogh, Montana,
and with troops in the field Bat-
talion 1st Cavalry from Dec. 16,
1890 to Jan. 29, 1891 - detached du-
ty Examining Board, West Point, N.Y.
June 6 to 19, 1891 - member Army
Med. Board, New York City, N.Y., Oct.
1 to 31, 1891.

En route to and on duty at
Ft. Snelling, Minn., from Nov. 7, 1891
to Aug. 21, 1892, during which time
was on detached duty with Battal-
ion, 3d Inf., at Indian Reservation
from April 1, 1892 to April 19, 1892;

At Hdqrs. Dept. of Dakota, St.
Paul. Minn., as Attending Surgeon
and Examiner of Receruits Aug. 21,
1892 to Aug. 31, 1893, during which
time was in temporary charge Med.
Director's Office from March 24 to
May 5, 1893. May 15 to 23, 1893, June
28 to 30, 1893, and July 1, 1893 to
3--958
Write nothing below this line.
July 15, 1893.

En route to and on duty in
Surgeon General's Office, Curator
Army Med. Museum from Sept. 6, 1893
to date, during which time was ex-
amined for promotion and found
qualified Sept. 1893. Member Army
Med. Board Sept. 11, 1893 to Oct. 21,
1893, per paragraph 23, S.O. 192, A.G.
O., Aug. 23, 1893. Professor clinical
and sanitary microscopy and direct-
or pathological laboratory in com-
pliance with G.O. 78, A.G.O., Sept. 22
1893. Promoted Surgeon with the
rank of Maj. Dec, 4. 1893. Member Ar-
my Med. Board Oct. 1 to 31, 1895, per
paragraph 2, S.O. 224, A.G.O., Sept. 25
1895. On detached duty en route to
and returning from Key West, Fla.,
July 22, 1896, to Aug. 7, 1896. Member
Army Med. Board Sept. 23, 1896 to Oct.
27, 1896, per paragraph 7, S.O. 196, A.
G.O., Aug. 20, 1896; Sept. 27, 1896 to
Nov. 6, 1897, per paragraph 1 S.O. 152
A.G.O., July 1, 1897; and May 2, 1898
to July 12, 1898, per paragraph 1,
S.O. 51, A.G.O., March 3, 1898, member
“Cholera” band board.

On detached duty making an
inspection of camps and field hos-
pital Aug. 1, 1898 to Aug. 8, 1898.
Member typhoid fever board to in-
spect certain camps Aug. 20, 1898 to
Sept. 18, 1898. Member of board in-
vestigating causes of typhoid fev-
er Sept. 25 to 30, 1898. Same duty
as above on typhoid fever board
Oct. 1 to 10, 1898. Inspecting build-
ings at Natural Bridge, Va. from Oct
18 to 25, 1898. En route to, at, and
returning from inspection duty at
Puerto Principe, Cuba, from April 19
1899 to May 9, 1899. On detached du-
ty at Ft. Thomas, Ky., from Sept. 28
to 30, 1899. Delegate to American
Public Health Association at Min-
neapolis, Minn. Oct. 31, 1899 to Nov.
3, 1899. En route to, on duty at Tam-
pa, Fla., and Havana, Cuba, on investi-
gation as to use of electrozone as
a disinfectant and germicide in
Havana, and return to station March
7 to April 3, 1900.

En route to and on duty as
member of board at Camp Columbia,
Cuba, investigation of diseases on
Island of Cuba, June 26, 1900 to Ju-
ly 31, 1900.

En route to Surgeon General's
Office from detached duty in Cuba,
3--958
Write nothing below this line.
Aug. 1 to 9, 1900. En route to and
on detached duty in Cuba relative
to causes of yellow fever from Sep.
29, 1900 to Oct. 13, 1900. En route
to U.S. from Havana, Cuba, from Oct.
14 to 20, 1900. Delegate to Ameri-
can Public Health Association, In-
dianapolis, Ind. Oct. 21 to 27, 1900.

En route to and returning
from detached duty in Cuba when in-
vestigating infectious diseases
prevalent on the Island of Cuba,
Nov. 1, 1900 to Feb. 12, 1901. Member
Army Med. Board from Feby. 11, 1901,
to present date, per paragraph 14,
S.O. 38, A.G.O., Feb. 14, 1901. Repre-
sented the Med. Dept. of the Army
at the meeting of the Pan American
Congress in Havana, Cuba, Feby. 1901.
Delegate to American Public Health
Association at Buffalo, N.Y., Sept.
16 to 20, 1901.

G.M.S., S.G., U.S.A.
S.G.O., Jan. 2, 1902.
B.M.I.

Major Walter Reed.
Surgeon, U.S. Army,
Army Med. Museum.

Official copy of above sent to
the Officer-in-charge. Museum and
Library Division, S.G.O., for his
information.
B.M.I.

Nov. 1, 1902.
To the Adjutant Gener-
al of the Army. Sir: I have the
honor to request that Major Walter
Reed, surgeon, U.S. Army, be ordered
to proceed to Fort H.G. Wright, Fish-
er's Island, N.Y., to investigate
and report upon the epidemic of ty-
phoid fever among the troops quar-
tered there during the recent man-
euvers in that vicinity, and upon
completion of this duty to return
to his proper station in this city.

R.M.O'R., S.G., U.S.A.
B.M.I.

C.O. Gen. Hosp. Wash Bks,
D.C. Nov 23. Reports death
of Major Walter Reed, Surg.
U.S.A., at that hospital at
five minutes after two
o'clock a.m. this date.

L Apr. 4, 1902
The President
and Faculty, Columbian
Univ., Wash., D.C., Mar. 27
Commend Major Walter Reed
for promotion and prefer-
ment on account of his
valuable services in con-
nection with the study
of yellow fever.
W.E.E.

L. 1ST ENDORSEMENT.
Apr. 5, 1902.
Respectfully for-
warded to the ADJUTANT GENER-
AL OF THE ARMY.

G.M.S.
S.G.
U.S.A.
W.

M. Sept. 4, 1902.
Surg. Genl. Forwards Efficiency
Report of Maj. Walter Reed
for June 3rd 1902.
R

Sept 5 '02 Noted
Noel

Nov. 1, 1902.
Major Walter Reed, Sur-
geon, U.S. Army, in addition to his
present duties, is hereby assigned
to duty as Librarian, in charge of
the Library of the S.G.O.
R.M.O'R., S.G., U.S.A.

3--958
Write nothing below this line.

Primary cause of death,
was acute appendicitis,
immediate cause of death,
was asthenia.
B.
N. 1st Indorsement.

Nov. 24, 1902.
Resp'y forwarded
to the ADJUTANT GENERAL, U.S. ARMY

The death of Maj. Reed is a
heavy blow to the Army and to
American Medical Science.

His services have already
proved almost priceless to the
nation, and had he been spared
even more might have been expect-
ed of him. His qualities as a
man so endeared him to his asso-
ciates that they feel his loss
as a personal calamity.

R.M.O'R., S.G., U.S.A.
(JFHM)
N. TELEGRAM.

November 23, 1902.
Walter L. Reed,
Nemorense 10th U.S. Infty. Manila

Your father Coppino - died
to-day.

O'Reilly
B.M.I.
Write nothing above this line.
TELEGRAM.

Nov. 23, 1902.
Dr. S. Weir Mitchell,
1524 Walnut St., Philadelphia, Pa.

Dr. Walter Reed died today.
Funeral Tuseday two o'clock.

R.M. O'Reilly,
Surgeon General.
B.M.I.
TELEGRAM.

Nov. 23, 1902.
Lieut. Col. John S. Bil-
lings, Astor Library. New York.

Major Walter Reed died to-
day. Funeral Tuesday two o'clock.

O'Reilly,
Surgeon General.
B.M.I.
TELEGRAM.

Nov. 23, 1902.
Prof. Wm. H. Welch, Johns
Hopkins University, Baltimore, Md.

Dr. Walter Reed died to-day.
Funeral two p.m. Tuesday.

R.M. O'Reilly,
Surgeon General
B.M.I.

W.H. Welch. Balto. Md. Nov.
24, 1902. Tel. “Reed's death is a
great loss to the Army and the Country.
Shall attend the funeral”.
R.

P. Nov. 25, 1902.
A.G. Forwards official copy of let.
tr C.O. Wash. Bks D.C.
Informing him that the Battn of Engineers
and Band act as escort [unclear] the funeral
of Surgeon Reed 25th inst. Command
to be at St. Thomas Episcopal Church at
2 p.m. Battn escort remains to Va End
of aqueduct bridge where cavalry will relieve
them &c.

Q. Nov. 25, 1902.
A. G. Howards
Copy of tel. to C.O. Ft. Myer Va-
Mr. 24-02. Informing him that Sec. War
directs him furnish as escort for funeral
late Maj. Walter Reed Med. Dept. band and
at least 3 troops of Cavalry-four if Capt.
Mc Blains's funeral does not interfere
to be at Va End Aqueduct Bridge
about 3 p.m. Tuesday 25th- A

R. Dec. 2. 1902
C. O., U.S. G.H.
Washington Bks. Nov. 30. 02.
Encloses bill for $ 600 due
that hospital under A.R.
1641 in case of the late Major
Walter Reed, from Nov. 17-
22. 1902., and requests that
the amount be remitted.

1 enclos.
G.

R. 1st Indorsement.
Dec. 2, 1902.

Respectfully returned to the
C.O., U.S.A. General Hospital, Wash. Bar-
racks, D.C., approved as within recom-
mended.

R.M.O'R, S.G.
FH

Dec. 2, 1902.
ORDERS. Under
the provisions of paragraph
97 Army Regulations, 1901, a
Board of Survey to consist of
Colonel Calvin DeWitt, Asst.
Surgeon General, U.S. Army, Capt.
Carl R. Darnall, Asst. Surgeon, U.
S. Army, and 1st Lieut. James
Carroll, Asst. Surgeon, U.S. Army,
is hereby appointed to inven-
tory the public property or
funds for which the late Walter
Reed, Surgeon, U.S.A., was re-
sponsible and make the customary
returns.
R.M.O'R. S.G. U.S.A. JGS
N Dec. 3, rec'd, break informally.

Dec. 3, 1902.
Respectfully re-
ferred to Major W.C. Borden,
Surgeon, U.S. Army, Commanding
U.S. General Hospital, Washing-
ton Barracks, D.C., for ex-
pression of opinion as to
whether the disease which the
late Major Walter Reed died
originated in service and in
line of duty.
R.M.O'R. S.G. U.S.A. JGS

N' Dec. 8, 1902
C.O., G.H., Wash.
Bks., D.C., Dec. 6 Certifies
that the disease from
which Maj. Walter Reed,
Surg., died in that hosp.
Nov. 23, 1902, originated in
the service and in the
line of duty.
N.E.E.
N.

2d Indorsement.
Dec. 8, 1902.
Reso. ret. to the A.G. of the Army,
inviting attention to enclosed
certificate of Maj. W.C. Borden,
Surg. U.S.A., Comdg. U.S. General
Hospital, Washington Barracks, D.C.
dated Dec. 6, 1902, as to origin of
disease from which Major Walter
Reed, Surg. U.S.A., died.
R.M.O'R., S.G.
FC
